expanded_description: Net force is the vector sum of all forces acting on an object. It determines whether and how the object accelerates. Understanding how to calculate and interpret net force is essential for applying Newton's laws and predicting motion.

core_concept.principle: The net force (also called resultant force or total force) is the single force that has the same effect as all the individual forces acting on an object combined. Mathematically, net force is the vector sum of all forces: $\vec{F}_{\text{net}} = \sum \vec{F} = \vec{F}_1 + \vec{F}_2 + \vec{F}_3 + ...$. The net force determines acceleration according to Newton's Second Law.
core_concept.explanation: Objects rarely experience just one force—usually multiple forces act simultaneously. A book on a table experiences gravity (downward) and normal force (upward). A sliding block experiences applied force (forward), friction (backward), gravity (down), and normal force (up). To predict motion, we must combine all forces into a single net force. Since forces are vectors, we add them using vector addition: forces in the same direction add, forces in opposite directions subtract. The net force is what actually matters for motion—if you push a box with 50 N but friction opposes with 20 N, the box responds to the net 30 N forward force, not to the individual forces separately. Three scenarios arise: (1) Net force = 0 (balanced forces): no acceleration, constant velocity (Newton's First Law). (2) Net force ≠ 0 in one direction (unbalanced forces): acceleration in that direction (Newton's Second Law). (3) Net force ≠ 0 changing direction: acceleration changes direction. Understanding net force connects force analysis to motion prediction, bridging Newton's laws with kinematics.

image.caption: Net force: vector sum of all individual forces acting on object. Determines acceleration.

sections.section_title: Calculating Net Force in One Dimension
sections.introduction: When forces act along a single line (one-dimensional motion), calculating net force involves adding and subtracting magnitudes with attention to direction.

key_concept.definition: In one dimension, choose a positive direction (typically right or up), then add forces in positive direction and subtract forces in negative direction. Net force: $F_{\text{net}} = F_{\text{positive direction}} - F_{\text{negative direction}}$. The sign of the result indicates net force direction: positive = positive direction, negative = negative direction.
key_concept.context: One-dimensional force problems are common: objects sliding horizontally (forces left/right), objects moving vertically (forces up/down), objects on inclines (forces along slope). Systematic approach prevents sign errors.

principles.statement: Before calculating, establish which direction is positive. Common conventions: right = positive (horizontal), up = positive (vertical). Be consistent throughout problem.
principles.application: Write at top of work: 'positive direction: right' or 'positive direction: up.'
principles.example: Horizontal motion: let right = positive. Force 30 N right = +30 N. Force 10 N left = -10 N.

principles.statement: Forces pointing in positive direction contribute positively to net force.
principles.application: If right is positive: rightward forces are positive values.
principles.example: Applied force 40 N to right, another push 15 N to right. Contribution to net force: +40 + 15 = +55 N.

principles.statement: Forces pointing in negative direction contribute negatively to net force (subtract from positive forces).
principles.application: If right is positive: leftward forces are negative values.
principles.example: Friction 20 N to left opposes rightward motion. Contribution to net force: -20 N.

principles.statement: $F_{\text{net}} = \sum F_{\text{right}} - \sum F_{\text{left}}$ (if right is positive). Or $F_{\text{net}} = \sum F_{\text{up}} - \sum F_{\text{down}}$ (if up is positive).
principles.application: Add all forces in positive direction, subtract all forces in negative direction.
principles.example: Forces right: 50 N, 20 N. Forces left: 30 N, 15 N. $F_{\text{net}} = (50 + 20) - (30 + 15) = 70 - 45 = 25$ N to the right.

principles.statement: Positive net force → acceleration in positive direction. Negative net force → acceleration in negative direction. Zero net force → no acceleration.
principles.example: $F_{\text{net}} = +15$ N: object accelerates to right (if right is positive). $F_{\text{net}} = -8$ N: object accelerates to left. $F_{\text{net}} = 0$ N: no acceleration (constant velocity).

worked_examples.title: Net Force with Two Opposing Forces
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg box is pushed to the right with 40 N force. Friction opposes with 15 N to the left. Find net force.

step_by_step.explanation: Applied force: +40 N (right, positive). Friction: -15 N (left, negative).
Positive net force → acceleration to the right. Magnitude: 25 N.

worked_examples.final_answer: $F_{\text{net}} = +25$ N to the right (or 25 N to the right)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Net force = sum of all forces with signs. Positive result means net force in positive (rightward) direction.

worked_examples.title: Vertical Forces - Balanced
worked_examples.problem: A 3 kg book rests on a table. Gravity pulls down with 29.4 N. Normal force pushes up. Find: (a) magnitude of normal force, (b) net force.

step_by_step.explanation: Book at rest → no acceleration → net force = 0. $F_{\text{net}} = F_N + F_g = 0$. $F_N + (-29.4) = 0$
Forces balanced (normal = weight). Net force zero → no acceleration → at rest (constant velocity of zero). Confirms Newton's First Law.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Normal force = 29.4 N upward, (b) Net force = 0 N
worked_examples.concept_applied: At rest → net force = 0. Vertical forces must balance. Normal force adjusts to balance weight for stationary object on horizontal surface.

worked_examples.title: Multiple Forces in Same Direction
worked_examples.problem: Three people push a car: Person A pushes right with 200 N, Person B pushes right with 180 N, Person C pushes left with 100 N. Friction opposes right with 150 N. Find net force.

step_by_step.explanation: Person A: +200 N. Person B: +180 N. Total right: $200 + 180 = 380$ N
Person C: -100 N. Friction: -150 N. Total left: $100 + 150 = 250$ N (magnitude)
Net force 130 N to the right. Car will accelerate to the right.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Sum all forces in positive direction, sum all forces in negative direction, subtract. Multiple forces in same direction add together.

worked_examples.title: Net Force Causing Deceleration
worked_examples.problem: A car moving to the right experiences air resistance 50 N to the left and friction 80 N to the left. Engine provides 40 N to the right. Find net force and describe motion.

step_by_step.explanation: Air resistance: -50 N. Friction: -80 N. Total left: 50 + 80 = 130 N magnitude

Negative net force (to the left) while car moving to the right → acceleration to the left → deceleration (slowing down). Car will slow down, eventually stop, then accelerate to the left if forces continue.

worked_examples.final_answer: $F_{\text{net}} = -90$ N (90 N to the left). Car decelerates (slows down) because net force opposes motion direction.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Negative net force when moving in positive direction = deceleration. Net force opposite to velocity direction causes slowing down.

image.alt: Diagram showing multiple horizontal forces and calculation of net force
image.caption: Net force in 1D: sum forces in positive direction, subtract forces in negative direction. Sign indicates direction.

sections.introduction: The distinction between balanced and unbalanced forces is fundamental to understanding motion according to Newton's laws.

key_concept.definition: Balanced forces: all forces cancel out, net force = 0, no acceleration (constant velocity including rest). Unbalanced forces: forces don't cancel, net force ≠ 0, acceleration occurs in direction of net force.
key_concept.context: This distinction directly connects to Newton's First and Second Laws. Balanced forces → First Law applies (constant velocity). Unbalanced forces → Second Law applies (acceleration proportional to net force).

principles.statement: Forces are balanced when their vector sum equals zero: $\sum \vec{F} = 0$. Object has no acceleration (may be at rest or moving at constant velocity).
principles.application: Check if forces cancel in all directions. If yes → balanced → no acceleration.
principles.example: Book on table: gravity 10 N down, normal 10 N up. Forces balance → net = 0 → at rest. Puck on ice at constant 5 m/s: minimal friction, forces essentially balanced → constant velocity continues.

principles.statement: Forces are unbalanced when vector sum is non-zero: $\sum \vec{F} \neq 0$. Object accelerates in direction of net force.
principles.application: If forces don't cancel → unbalanced → acceleration occurs.
principles.example: Pushed box: push 30 N right, friction 10 N left. Unbalanced (net = 20 N right) → accelerates to right. Falling object: gravity 100 N down, air resistance 20 N up. Unbalanced (net = 80 N down) → accelerates downward.

principles.principle: Balanced Forces Don't Mean No Forces
principles.statement: Balanced forces means net force is zero, not that no forces act. Multiple forces can be present but cancel out.
principles.example: Object at rest on table: gravity and normal force both present (two forces), but balanced → net = 0. Very different from object in deep space with truly no forces.

principles.statement: Cannot determine if forces balanced by looking at whether object moves. Must check if accelerating. Moving at constant velocity → balanced. Moving with changing velocity → unbalanced.
principles.application: Constant velocity (including v = 0) → balanced. Acceleration → unbalanced.
principles.example: Car cruising at constant 100 km/h: moving, but forces balanced (engine force = air resistance + friction) → no acceleration. Car speeding up from 50 to 100 km/h: forces unbalanced → accelerating.

characteristics: Forces in opposite directions have equal magnitudes

examples.explanation: Stationary → velocity = 0 (constant) → no acceleration → forces balanced. Book on shelf, parked car, hanging picture.
Velocity constant (not changing) → no acceleration → forces balanced. Puck sliding on ice at steady speed, car on cruise control at constant speed on level road.
Push 50 N right, friction 50 N left → net = 0 → balanced. Weight 98 N down, normal 98 N up → balanced.

characteristics: Forces in opposite directions have unequal magnitudes

examples.explanation: Car accelerating from stoplight → velocity increasing → acceleration → forces unbalanced (engine > friction).
Bike coasting to stop → velocity decreasing → deceleration (negative acceleration) → forces unbalanced (friction > forward motion maintenance).
Car turning corner at constant speed → direction changing → acceleration (direction change is acceleration) → forces unbalanced (friction provides inward force).
Push 80 N right, friction 30 N left → net = 50 N right ≠ 0 → unbalanced → accelerates right.

worked_examples.title: Determining Force Balance from Motion
worked_examples.problem: For each scenario, state if forces are balanced or unbalanced: (a) Car parked on level street, (b) Ball rolling at constant 3 m/s on level floor, (c) Bicycle accelerating from 5 m/s to 10 m/s, (d) Skydiver falling at constant terminal velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: At rest → velocity = 0 (constant) → no acceleration → forces balanced. Weight and normal force equal and opposite.
Constant velocity (3 m/s unchanging) → no acceleration → forces balanced. Minimal friction on level floor approximately balances any residual forward force.
Velocity changing (5 → 10 m/s) → acceleration present → forces unbalanced. Pedaling force > friction.
Constant velocity (downward, but constant) → no acceleration → forces balanced. Air resistance exactly equals weight at terminal velocity.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Balanced (at rest), (b) Balanced (constant velocity), (c) Unbalanced (accelerating), (d) Balanced (constant velocity—even though falling)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant velocity (including v = 0) → balanced forces. Changing velocity → unbalanced forces. Motion alone doesn't determine balance—acceleration does.

worked_examples.title: From Forces to Motion Prediction
worked_examples.problem: A 10 kg box experiences: gravity 98 N down, normal 98 N up, applied force 60 N right, friction 25 N left. (a) Are forces balanced? (b) Predict motion.

step_by_step.explanation: Up: normal 98 N. Down: gravity 98 N. Net vertical: $98 - 98 = 0$ N. Balanced vertically.
Right: applied 60 N. Left: friction 25 N. Net horizontal: $60 - 25 = 35$ N right. Unbalanced horizontally.
Vertical balanced, horizontal unbalanced. Overall: forces UNBALANCED (net force = 35 N right).

Unbalanced force to right → acceleration to right. Box will accelerate horizontally to the right. No vertical motion (vertical forces balanced). Magnitude of acceleration: $a = F_{\text{net}}/m = 35/10 = 3.5$ m/s² (preview of Second Law).

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Unbalanced (net force 35 N right). (b) Box accelerates to the right; no vertical motion.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Check forces in each direction separately. Unbalanced in any direction → acceleration in that direction. Can have balance in one direction, imbalance in another.

image.alt: Two diagrams: balanced forces showing equal opposite arrows and stationary object, unbalanced showing unequal arrows and accelerating object
image.caption: Balanced forces (net = 0): constant velocity. Unbalanced forces (net ≠ 0): acceleration.

sections.introduction: When forces act in multiple directions (not along a single line), calculating net force requires vector addition in two dimensions.

key_concept.definition: For forces in two dimensions, resolve each force into x and y components, sum all x-components to get net x-force, sum all y-components to get net y-force, then combine using Pythagorean theorem to find net force magnitude and trigonometry to find direction: $F_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{F_{\text{net},x}^2 + F_{\text{net},y}^2}$, $\theta = \tan^{-1}(F_{\text{net},y}/F_{\text{net},x})$.
key_concept.context: Two-dimensional force problems are common: forces at angles (pulling wagon upward at angle, wind pushing at angle), perpendicular forces (gravity down, applied force horizontally), forces on inclined planes. Component method systematically handles any combination.

principles.statement: Break each angled force into x and y components: $F_x = F \cos \theta$, $F_y = F \sin \theta$ where $\theta$ is angle from x-axis. Sum components separately: $F_{\text{net},x} = \sum F_x$, $F_{\text{net},y} = \sum F_y$.
principles.application: Establish x-y coordinate system, resolve all forces, sum by components.
principles.example: Force 50 N at 30° above horizontal: $F_x = 50 \cos 30° = 43.3$ N, $F_y = 50 \sin 30° = 25$ N.

principles.statement: Net force components $F_{\text{net},x}$ and $F_{\text{net},y}$ form a right triangle. Magnitude: $F_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{F_{\text{net},x}^2 + F_{\text{net},y}^2}$. Direction: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(F_{\text{net},y}/F_{\text{net},x})$.
principles.application: After summing components, use Pythagorean theorem and inverse tangent.
principles.example: $F_{\text{net},x} = 40$ N, $F_{\text{net},y} = 30$ N. Magnitude: $\sqrt{40^2 + 30^2} = \sqrt{2500} = 50$ N. Angle: $\tan^{-1}(30/40) = 36.9°$ above horizontal.

principles.statement: Typical: right = +x, left = -x, up = +y, down = -y. Forces in negative directions have negative components.
principles.example: Force 20 N to the left and down at 45° below horizontal (third quadrant): $F_x = -20 \cos 45° = -14.1$ N, $F_y = -20 \sin 45° = -14.1$ N.

worked_examples.title: Perpendicular Forces
worked_examples.problem: Two forces act on an object: 30 N to the right, 40 N upward. Find net force magnitude and direction.
worked_examples.final_answer: Net force: 50 N at 53.1° above horizontal (to the right and up)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Perpendicular forces: components already separated. Use Pythagorean theorem for magnitude, inverse tangent for direction.

worked_examples.title: Force at an Angle
worked_examples.problem: A force of 100 N acts at 37° above the horizontal to the right. A friction force of 30 N acts to the left. Find net force.
worked_examples.final_answer: Net force: 78.2 N at 50.4° above horizontal
worked_examples.concept_applied: Angled force: resolve into components using sine and cosine. Sum all x-components, sum all y-components, combine for net force.

image.alt: Diagram showing multiple forces at angles, their components, and resultant net force
image.caption: Net force in 2D: resolve forces into x and y components, sum separately, combine using Pythagorean theorem

sections.introduction: Recognizing common force scenarios and knowing what net force to expect helps solve problems systematically.

categories.type: Object at Rest on Horizontal Surface
categories.description: Stationary object on table, floor, ground.

examples.explanation: Gravity (weight) downward: $F_g = mg$. Normal force upward: $F_N$. If no horizontal forces: no friction needed.
Object at rest → net force = 0. Vertical: $F_N - F_g = 0$ → $F_N = F_g = mg$. Horizontal: no forces → net = 0.
Balanced forces. No acceleration. Remains at rest (First Law).

categories.description: Box pushed at steady speed, puck gliding on ice.

examples.explanation: Applied force forward, friction backward, gravity down, normal up.
Constant velocity → net force = 0. Vertical: $F_N = F_g$ (balanced). Horizontal: $F_{\text{applied}} = f$ (friction equals applied force).
Balanced forces. No acceleration. Constant velocity continues (First Law).

categories.description: Car speeding up, box being pushed with increasing speed.

examples.explanation: Applied force forward, friction backward, gravity down, normal up.
Accelerating → net force ≠ 0 in direction of acceleration. Vertical: $F_N = F_g$ (no vertical acceleration). Horizontal: $F_{\text{applied}} > f$ → net force forward.
Unbalanced horizontal forces. Accelerates in direction of net force (Second Law).
Only gravity (weight) downward. No normal force (not on surface), no air resistance (idealized).
Only one force → net force = gravity = $mg$ downward.
Unbalanced force downward. Accelerates downward at $a = g = 9.8$ m/s² (Second Law).

categories.description: Mass suspended from rope or string.

examples.explanation: Gravity (weight) downward: $F_g = mg$. Tension upward: $T$.
At rest → net force = 0. $T - F_g = 0$ → $T = mg$.
Balanced forces. Tension exactly equals weight for hanging object at rest.
Gravity (down), normal (perpendicular to surface), friction (along surface opposing motion).
Depends on angle and friction. Component of gravity along slope: $F_{\parallel} = mg \sin \theta$. If stationary: friction = $mg \sin \theta$. If sliding: net force = $mg \sin \theta - f$.
Complex—requires component analysis (covered in detail in later sections).

image.caption: Common situations: at rest (balanced forces), constant velocity (balanced), accelerating (unbalanced), free fall (only gravity)

summary: Net force (also called resultant force) is the vector sum of all forces acting on an object: $\vec{F}_{\text{net}} = \sum \vec{F} = \vec{F}_1 + \vec{F}_2 + ...$. The net force determines acceleration according to Newton's laws. In one dimension, calculate net force by choosing a positive direction, adding forces in positive direction, subtracting forces in negative direction: $F_{\text{net}} = F_{\text{positive}} - F_{\text{negative}}$. Sign of result indicates direction: positive = positive direction, negative = negative direction, zero = no net force. Balanced forces occur when net force = 0 (forces cancel out). Results: no acceleration, constant velocity (including rest as special case), First Law applies. Examples: object at rest on table (normal = weight), object sliding at constant velocity (applied = friction). Unbalanced forces occur when net force ≠ 0 (forces don't cancel). Results: acceleration in direction of net force, Second Law applies. Examples: car speeding up (engine > friction), free fall (only gravity). Important: cannot determine force balance from motion alone—must check acceleration. Constant velocity (including v=0) → balanced. Changing velocity → unbalanced. In two dimensions, use component method: (1) resolve each force into x and y components using $F_x = F \cos \theta$ and $F_y = F \sin \theta$, (2) sum all x-components: $F_{\text{net},x} = \sum F_x$, (3) sum all y-components: $F_{\text{net},y} = \sum F_y$, (4) combine using Pythagorean theorem: $F_{\text{net}} = \sqrt{F_{\text{net},x}^2 + F_{\text{net},y}^2}$, (5) find direction: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(F_{\text{net},y}/F_{\text{net},x})$. Common scenarios: object at rest on surface (normal = weight, net = 0), object at constant velocity (all forces balanced, net = 0), accelerating object (applied > friction horizontally, net ≠ 0), free fall (only gravity, net = mg downward), hanging object at rest (tension = weight, net = 0). Understanding net force bridges force identification to motion prediction, connecting Newton's First Law (net force = 0 → constant velocity) and Second Law (net force ≠ 0 → acceleration).
